text: hey everybody thomas joseph here with
another kitchen conundrum now I'm sure
you've seen needs in the supermarket or
maybe at the farmers market and you
thought what the heck do I do with these
vegetables how do I even cook them well
today I'm going to demystify some
autumnal vegetables and give you really
great suggestions on how you could cook
them and today I'm going to start off
with a celery root which is what I have
in my hand here celery root is not the
same plant as the celery stalks it's
within the same family but it's slightly
different and now it is a root vegetable
so peel it first you can of course use
one of these hand peelers to peel away
the skin but it is quite thick and there
are these little craters and bumps kind
of like a pineapple I would say so it's
almost best to treat it like that and to
use a knife which makes it much easier
and faster so if you cut off the bottom
and the top and then you kind of glide
your knife down around the sides what
you do is you trim away all of that skin
what I'm going to show you today is a
celery root puree to cut this into
1-inch cubes and cutting into even
pieces ensures that the celery root is
cooked evenly so cut the celery root
into planks and then cut them into
sticks and then cubes from there and now
I have a pot of water here set over a
burner this is cold water so it's very
much the same way you would do mashed
potatoes season them up with a little
bit of salt and now you're gonna bring
this to a boil you're going to reduce to
a simmer and cover and simmer for about
20 to 25 minutes until the celery root
is nice and tender so the celery root
it's super tender drain and puree it
so I'm using a food processor here today
to delay the celery root now with
something like a potato or sweet potato
something that has more starch you
should never use a food processor or a
blender but celery root is actually very
low in starch so it won't get gluey or
gummy now to this add one cup of milk
and three tablespoons of butter melted
together and I'm gonna process this
until it's in fine
cure a so now just give it a little bit
of salt and pepper process this together
and you could certainly pass this
through a fine sieve to get a silky
smooth puree and then next up I have a
kohlrabi kohlrabi is a member of the
cruciferous family and cruciferous
vegetables are broccoli cauliflower
collard greens start off by trimming
away the leaves now you don't want to
discard the leaves because we're gonna
do something with them later but I'm
going to first tackle the bulb of the
kohlrabi you can cook it or you can also
eat it raw so today I'm gonna show you a
kohlrabi and green apple slaw now if
you're trying to figure out what the
texture and the taste of kohlrabi is
it's very similar to broccoli stems now
I'm just gently trimming away the tough
skin on the outside if you have big
kohlrabi these are kind of I would say
medium-sized kohlrabi but what you
should do is you should split the bulb
in half and see if there's a tough core
which kind of around this area there's
it's a little bit more fibrous and tough
and chewy so what you can do is you can
trim this out now what I'm gonna do
cut the kohlrabi into thin planks I
would say about a quarter of an inch
thickness and then simply glide through
cutting little matchsticks and they go
right into a bowl so you could also
roast kohlrabi you can throw it into
soups and stews
you could steam it you can boil it and
then mash it it's really really one of
those great versatile vegetables so I
have about three bulbs of kohlrabi here
that I've cut up into matchsticks and at
one green apple to that a tart sweet
apple like a Granny Smith is really
great it has the same texture but it has
a different flavor and then a little bit
of salt and pepper a lemon and then
olive oil so there you have it a super
simple kohlrabi slaw now those greens
that we have from the top of the
kohlrabi do not throw those away because
you can use them just like you would
collard greens give them a chop and
saute and a little bit of olive oil you
can do some garlic here you could put in
some onion chili flakes season it up
with some salt and pepper and you have a
really simple saute of kohlrabi greens
now you can serve the kohlrabi greens
just like this as a simple side two ways
to use kohlrabi the greens and the bulb
and now next I'm gonna show you what you
can do with a kabocha squash and this is
a Kenosha squash it is used widely in
Asia particularly in Korea and also
Japan and when you pick out a kabocha
squash when you see it at the
supermarket at the farmers market you
want to make sure that it seems heavy
for the size and you want to look for
this dark green color it has almost a
dull finish to it there are some
varietals of kabocha squash that are
orange in color on the outside but the
most common I would say is green when I
cut into this you're gonna actually get
to see the color of the flesh and that
is a bright orange color so I'm just
gonna cut right through the middle
use a heavy-duty knife here the flavor
of kabocha squash it's very similar to
like if you crossed a sweet potato and a
pumpkin together it has a slightly
spongy texture you can see the color it
looks really beautiful it has this
mustardy orange color Kabuto squash is
really great if you steam it you can
throw it into soups you could roast it
like I'm going to do today
I'm gonna scrape out the seeds cut these
into one-inch wedges
how do I'm gonna preheated to 450
degrees because you want to roast it a
high high temperature and these will
take anywhere from 25 to 35 minutes
depending on how large your squash is
and a little bit of olive oil drizzled
that over the top season with salt and
pepper you could certainly use your
favorite spice blend here you could
throw in some herbs if you'd like some
woodsy herbs like thyme would be really
great sage would be really nice
especially this time of the year and I
just kind of like I like to toss the
squash right on the sheet tray coating
both sides with oil and salt and pepper
it's always best to give them a good
flip halfway through so that both sides
get evenly cooked so into the oven so
the commercial squash is out of the oven
you can see that it changes in color it
gets a really rich orange color so there
you go so next time you see commotions
squash kohlrabi or celery root in the
marketplace don't be intimidated or
fearful and pick them up and try some of
these really great recipes I'm sure
you're going to enjoy them
you
